ANS:correct.  INFO:start from the left all the way to right    FIRST_SET: 5 ones (1) after that apply zero (0)  continue the pattern...   SECOND_SET:6 ones(1) so -> 5 ones(1)  then zero(0) then one(1) continue the pattern...   THIRD_SET:7 ones(1) so -> 5 ones(1) then zero(0) then one(1) then (1)  continue the pattern...

Correct Mate :)

Actually, after 5 consecutive 1s ,a zero will be placed irrespective of the next bit (0 or 1). So, at the receiver end this 0 will be removed to get the original sequence.  example the body part is 111110010001111110 at sender end. So, the pattern received at the receiving end will be 11111o00100011111o10  (i intentionally used 'o' for denoting the extra 0's).

thank you

Correct.  The original bit sequence without bit stuffing is "110101111101011111101011111110".  After applying bit stuffing, the bit sequence becomes "110101111100101111101010111110110". Here, bit stuffing involves inserting an extra "0" bit after every sequence of five consecutive "1" bits to ensure that the receiver can distinguish between the original "1" bits and the stuffed "0" bits. The stuffed bit sequence is still able to convey the same information as the original bit sequence.
It is correct.

it is not possible to have 6 or more consecutive 1's in the sequence because the sender always stuffs 0s after every five 1's. So, the sender has to keep track of (01)'s in the sequence, to remove the (0) from it, if the next five bits are all 1's.

Answer to H.W. at 03:50  Given Bit Sequence without Bit Stuffing (I think there is No Beginning and Ending Sequence) : 110101111101011111101011111110  I as a Sender taking that data bits sequence from upper layer and see three "5 Consecutive 1's". What are they ?  1101011111(1st)01011111(2nd)101011111(3rd)110    Put 1st=2nd=3rd=0  1101011111(0)01011111(0)101011111(0)110 = Given Bit Sequence with Bit Stuffing in video.  Hence, It is Correct.
Thank you so much

Idk what you meant, but the solution is correct. Look at it from the receiver's point of view (the receiver is on the left). The receiver will read 5 1's then a 0 which it will remove. The order is definitely correct

great question. any idea?

@vegaripkont792  Hi! So basically the reciever assumes that bit stuffing was applied and just mindlessly removes any zeroes appearing after five consecutive ones. If there is a zero after five consecutive ones in the original data, then bit stuffing would still add a zero after five ones, making five ones and two zeroes, and reciever will just remove one zero after five ones making it back to how it was!

@rahulkumarsingh7615  can you elaborate this as to why we still need to insert 0 deliberately? Since the ending would be different than that part of the message, there shouldn’t be any problem in receiving the data?

@RahulSharma-oc2qd  there is a fix mechanism. if after consecutive 1's the next one was already 0  and if we don't one more 0 then at the receiver side the mechanism will remove the 0 after consecutive 1's. it's better to put 0 irrespective of there is already 0 present in the data after consecutive 1's. see this example : data - 011011011111011  after bit stuffing -  110110111110011   at the receiver side -  after removing the extra 0 bit data - 011011011111011  so it's correct data at the receiver side.  if we do not put 0 (bit stuffing)  while sending the data - 011011011111011   at the receiver side -   the mecanism will remove the 0 after consecutive 5 times 1's so the data will be - 01101101111111 Now it's incorrect data we are getting at the receiver side.  i hope you understand it

Just remember - whenever 5 consecutive 1's appear, a 0 will be inserted by the sender, independent of the next value(be it 0 or 1)  Whenever receiver encounters 5 consecutive 1's, it will remove a 0 after it except for begining and the end.

You must know which part is the start frame delimiter, Then you start counting the 1's from that side. The basic idea is, the End delimiter must not be the same as the part of data, otherwise, that part of the data will be considered as the End delimiter and only half of the data will be read.
It's seems wrong because you loose the beginning sequence after it's bit stuffed
@brod515  do you have any clear explanation for this bit stuffing? Because I don't really understand that question haha
@nesoacademy same doubt sir

Say the payload we get from the network layer includes something like ...1111101... Since we first do bit stuffing, it'll go like ...11111001... And the receiver will remove 0 after five 1s in a row and eventually gets the original data, which is ...1111101... So in your example, you did not do bit stuffing at the sender side and yet you've removed 0 after five 1s at the receiver side. So that causes the confusion.

If bit stuffing is not done in sender side, then in the receiver side 0 is not removed.. As both nodes follow one protocol, what is done is sender side should be reversed in Reciever side.. As bit suffing is not done on sender side receiver will also not remove 0.. Only if bit stuffing is done, then only 0 is removed
